intro: Acoelorraphe cookii, commonly known as the Cook's acoelorraphe, is a flowering plant native to the island of Madagascar. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae, which includes many species with showy flowers and milky sap. The plant is characterized by its slender, branching stems and clusters of small, fragrant flowers that range in color from white to pink. Its leaves are typically opposite and have a smooth, waxy texture. Acoelorraphe cookii is often found in moist, shaded habitats within the rainforests of Madagascar.
